title: Bookworm Matty Johns has read the Koran twice!
text:
He's the lovable larrikin who became a household name on The Footy Show.

But it has been revealed that former NRL player Matty Johns is also a secret bookworm.

On Tuesday, Matty's wife Trish told realestate.com.au: 'Matt loves books, all nonfiction. He reads religion, geography and history. He’s read the Koran twice!'

'He’s read the Koran twice': Matty Johns wife Trish has revealed the NRL star (pictured) is a bookworm who loves reading about geography, religion and history

The revelation came after Trish discussed the couple’s Collaroy home in Sydney, which is currently for sale.

Belle Property describes the couple's family home as a 'seamless fusion of refined period charm and high-end contemporary design'.

The mansion offers luxury interiors as well as a spacious garden, a large swimming pool, and an outdoor lounge and dining area.

The eco-friendly property is also equipped with solar panels on the roof, and is conveniently located just minutes from the beach.

Reading between the lines: The revelation came after Trish (right) discussed the couple’s Collaroy home in Sydney, which is currently for sale

According to Realestate.com.au, Matty, 48, loved the friendly atmosphere of Sydney's Northern Beaches, after moving there from Newcastle.

'Collaroy is a blue-collar area. Every second bloke you run into is a tradesman,' said the former Newcastle Knights player.

'Coming from an old mining town like Cessnock, it might sound a bit funny but I regard ­myself as a coastal person now.'

Wow! The couple purchased the four-bedroom property in Collaroy for $3.585 million in 2007. It is now expected to fetch up to $6.3 million on the market. Pictured: the front of the house

Spacious: The French provincial-inspired home underwent major renovations in 2013, with its double garage being converted into a home gym. Pictured: one of the four bedrooms

He's a local! According to Realestate.com.au, Matty loved the friendly atmosphere of Sydney's Northern Beaches, after moving there from Newcastle. Pictured: the dining room

Matty is now a leading rugby league media personality and commentator, after retiring from the sport in 2002.

At the time, shoulder and neck injuries forced him to step away from the game after playing his last season with the Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks.

Matty went on to become a regular on The Footy Show, before it was axed. He now works at Fox Sports.
